thread.title: T-Mobile jumps on results; Whole Foods eyes lowest open since 2012
thread.title_full: T-Mobile jumps on results; Whole Foods eyes lowest open since 2012 - MarketWatch

author: By     Sue Chang   and   Mark DeCambre
title: T-Mobile jumps on results; Whole Foods eyes lowest open since 2012
text:
Bloomberg LinkedIn is scheduled to report quarterly reports after Thursday’s market close. These are the stocks likely to make notable moves in Thursday trade:
Gainers T-Mobile US Inc. TMUS, +3.81% jumped as much as 5.2% in premarket trade after the telecommunications company posted a better-than-expected second-quarter revenue of $8.2 billion, said it added 2.1 million subscribers, and raised its full-year subscriber outlook.
Wynn Resorts Ltd. WYNN, +5.94% reported its second-quarter earnings dropped to $56.5 million, or 56 cents a share, from $203.9 million, or $2 a share, a year earlier. Excluding items, the casino operator would have earned 74 cents a share while revenue fell 26% to $1.04 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expected 96 cents a share on $1.07 billion in revenue.
Air Products & Chemicals Inc . APD, +6.02% surged by more than 5% in premarket trade after it reported profit and revenue that beat Wall Street average estimates .
Decliners Whole Foods Market Inc. WFM, -11.22% was on track to open at its lowest level in three years Thursday after the company late Wednesday posted third-quarter earnings of 43 cents a share on revenue of $3.63 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated 45 cents a share on revenue of $3.69 billion.
Procter & Gamble Co. PG, -3.55% posted a better-than-expected profit of $521 million, or 18 cents a share, but the consumer-products giant missed on revenue and provided a downbeat outlook for its fiscal 2016 earnings .
Facebook Inc. FB, -4.18% was moving lower after the social media giant late Wednesday reported that its second-quarter earnings fell to $719 million, or 25 cents a share, from $791 million, or 30 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On an adjusted basis, Facebook would have earned 50 cents a share, better than 47 cents a share forecast by analysts. Revenue grew to $4.04 billion from $2.91 billion a year earlier
Tickers to Watch Time Warner Cable TWC, +0.13% missed Street estimates with a second-quarter profit of $463 million , or $1.62 a share, compared with average analysts’ estimates of $1.80. Excluding items, earnings were $1.54. The cable company did report a growth in subscribers.
ConocoPhillips COP, -0.81% posted a second-quarter profit of seven cents a share , excluding a tax charge, a $140 million impairment and other items—better than average analysts’ estimates of 4 cents a share. The energy company also cut its capital expenditures as energy prices fall.
Valero Energy Corp. VLO, -3.36% posted second-quarter profit that more than doubled , lifted by increasing efficiencies in its refining operations.
Mondelez MDLZ, +4.63% is expected to post second-quarter earnings of 39 cents a share, down from 40 cents a share a year ago.
Avon Products Inc. AVP, +1.39% is forecast to post earnings of 8 cents a share in the second quarter, down from 20 cents a share a year earlier.
After Thursday’s close of trading, Electronic Arts Inc. EA, -0.86% is likely to report fiscal first-quarter earnings of 2 cents a share, down from 19 cents a share.
Amgen Inc. AMGN, -1.04% is expected to report second-quarter earnings of $2.43 a share, up from $2.37 a share a year ago.
Expedia Inc. EXPE, +1.63% is projected to post second-quarter earnings of 84 cents a share, down from $1.03 a share a year earlier.
LinkedIn LNKD, -3.59% is likely to post second-quarter earnings of 30 cents a share, down from 51 cents a share a year ago.
